events.event_description: U.S. jet fuel consumption averaged 1.65 million barrels per day in 2023, remaining 5% below pre-pandemic levels despite three years of growth.
events.citation: U.S. jet fuel consumption averaged 1.65 million barrels per day (b/d) in 2023, 5% below the pre-pandemic high in 2019.

events.event_description: U.S. jet fuel consumption hit its lowest level since 1985 due to COVID-19 travel restrictions.
events.citation: In 2020, less jet fuel was consumed in the United States than in any year since 1985 due to reductions in air travel caused by the outbreak of COVID-19.

events.event_description: Foreign-based carriers reduced their capacity by 14% for U.S. international routes in 2023 compared to 2019, while U.S.-based carriers increased capacity.
events.citation: In terms of available seat-miles, a measure of aircraft carrying capacity, foreign-based carriers offered 14% less capacity in 2023 than in 2019 for routes between the United States and international destinations. Over the same period, U.S.-based carriers increased their capacity for international routes by 2% and for domestic routes by 4%.

events.event_description: Air freight activity declined 12% from 2021 to 2023 as supply chain constraints eased and consumer spending patterns normalized.
events.citation: Since then, freight activity from 2021 to 2023 declined 12% as supply chain constraints eased and spending on goods returned to typical levels, reducing jet fuel consumption by freight carriers.

events.event_description: U.S. commercial carriers improved fuel economy to 65.5 seat-miles per gallon in 2023, up from 64.9 in 2019.
events.citation: The average fuel economy of U.S. commercial carriers in terms of available seat-miles per gallon increased to 65.5 seat-miles per gallon in 2023 compared with 64.9 seat-miles per gallon in 2019.
